questions.text: Surfactant is secreted by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Type Il pneumocyte

Explanation:

  • Surfactant is a lipid-protein substance secreted by Type II pneumocytes in the alveoli of the lungs. Its primary function is to reduce surface tension within the alveoli, preventing alveolar collapse during exhalation and aiding in efficient gas exchange.
  • Type II pneumocytes are specialized alveolar cells that secrete surfactant starting from approximately 24 weeks of gestation, with sufficient production by 35 weeks to support normal respiration.

Clinical Insight:

  • A deficiency of surfactant in premature neonates leads to neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), characterized by difficulty in breathing and alveolar collapse. Surfactant replacement therapy is often used to treat this condition.

 

Type I pneumocyte (Option A): Type I pneumocytes are involved in gas exchange and form the thin alveolar lining, but they do not secrete surfactant.

Sertoli cell (Option C): Sertoli cells are found in the seminiferous tubules of the testes and play a role in sperm development (spermatogenesis).

Leydig cell (Option D): Leydig cells are located in the testes and are responsible for producing testosterone.

Explanation:

The Anion Gap (AG) calculated in the above scenario is 14mEq/L.

  • It measures the difference between measured cations and anions in the serum.
  • Formula:

  • In above ques: AG=142−(100+28) = 142−128 = 14 mEq/L​.

questions.text: The surface tension of the fluid lining the alveoli increases during ?

choices.text: Change in posture from standing to supine
Change in posture from supine to standing

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Inspiration

Explanation:

The surface tension in the alveoli is governed by the fluid lining the alveoli, and it changes with alveolar size. This is primarily regulated by pulmonary surfactant, which reduces surface tension.

During inspiration, the alveoli expand and increase in surface area

The surfactant becomes more spread out and less concentrated, leading to a relative increase in surface tension.

Conversely, during expiration, the alveoli shrink, surfactant becomes more concentrated, and surface tension decreases.

This is in accordance with Laplace's Law:

P = 2T/r

Where:

P = pressure required to keep alveolus open

T= surface tension

r= radius of alveolus

As the radius increases (inspiration), surface tension also increases unless adequately countered by surfactant.

 

 

Change in posture from standing to supine (Option B) - This posture change affects lung volumes and distribution of blood flow, but not directly the surface tension of alveolar fluid.

It may affect ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) matching, but not surface tension dynamics directly.

Expiration (Option C) - During expiration, alveoli decrease in size. Surfactants become more concentrated, reducing surface tension.

 

Change in posture from supine to standing (Option D) - Similar to option B, this may affect pulmonary perfusion and ventilation, but does not have a direct effect on surface tension of alveolar fluid.

questions.text: The diagram below shows the pressure–volume curves for 3 different lungs. Which of the following is the best representation of compliance between the three lungs?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: 

  • The pressure-volume curve of the lungs represents the relationship between the pressure applied to the lungs and the corresponding volume of air in the lungs. This curve helps us understand the behavior of the lungs during inspiration and expiration.
  • The pressure-volume curve of the lungs typically exhibits two phases: inflation and deflation.

During the inflation phase:

  • Initially, as the lung volume increases, the compliance of the lungs is high, meaning that the lungs easily expand with minimal changes in pressure.
  • As the lung volume continues to increase, the compliance gradually decreases. This is due to the stretching of the lung tissue and the increasing resistance to expansion.
  • At a certain point, the compliance reaches its lowest value, which is known as the lower inflection point. Beyond this point, the compliance increases again, indicating easier expansion of the lungs.

During the deflation phase:

  • Initially, as the lung volume decreases, the compliance remains relatively high, allowing the lungs to recoil passively.
  • As the lung volume further decreases, the compliance starts to decrease again, indicating increasing resistance to deflation.
  • At a certain point, the compliance reaches its highest value, which is known as the upper inflection point. Beyond this point, the compliance decreases again, indicating increasing resistance to deflation.
  • The pressure-volume curve of the lungs can provide valuable information about lung mechanics and can be used to assess lung diseases or evaluate the effects of therapeutic interventions. Changes in the shape and position of the curve can indicate alterations in lung compliance and resistance.

questions.text: In which of the subsequent situations does oxygen therapy prove to be ineffective?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Central respiratory depression

  • In cases of central respiratory depression, oxygen therapy may not be beneficial or effective.
  • Central respiratory depression refers to a decrease or cessation of breathing due to a suppressed respiratory drive in the central nervous system. In such cases, providing oxygen alone may not stimulate the respiratory centers enough to overcome the underlying cause of respiratory depression.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Asthma- Oxygen therapy can be beneficial in asthma exacerbations. In asthma, there is bronchoconstriction and inflammation of the airways, which can lead to reduced oxygen levels. Supplemental oxygen can help improve oxygenation and alleviate symptoms in individuals with asthma.
Option B: Acute myocardial infarction- Oxygen therapy is commonly used in the management of acute myocardial infarction (heart attack). It helps to increase oxygen supply to the heart muscle and improve oxygenation in the body. Providing supplemental oxygen during an acute myocardial infarction can help reduce myocardial damage and improve outcomes.
Option C: Pulmonary edema- This option is incorrect. Oxygen therapy is typically used in the management of pulmonary edema. Pulmonary edema is characterized by fluid accumulation in the lungs, leading to impaired gas exchange. Supplemental oxygen can help improve oxygenation and relieve respiratory distress in individuals with pulmonary edema.

questions.text: In peripheral oxygen sensing chemoreceptors, which ion is implicated?
questions.solution:
Correct option is A: Potassium.

  • Potassium ions (K+) are involved in peripheral oxygen-sensing chemoreceptors. These chemoreceptors, known as peripheral chemoreceptors or arterial chemoreceptors, are primarily located in the carotid bodies and aortic bodies. They detect changes in oxygen levels in the blood and play a crucial role in regulating respiratory and cardiovascular responses.

Incorrect options

Option B: Calcium ions (Ca2+) are not directly involved in peripheral oxygen-sensing chemoreceptors. However, calcium ions are important for various cellular processes and signaling pathways within the body.

Option C: Sodium ions (Na+) are not directly involved in peripheral oxygen-sensing chemoreceptors. Sodium ions play a critical role in maintaining the body's fluid balance, nerve impulse transmission, and muscle contraction.

Option D: Chlorine ions (Cl-) are not directly involved in peripheral oxygen-sensing chemoreceptors. Chlorine ions primarily function as an anion to maintain electrical neutrality and are involved in maintaining the osmotic balance and acid-base balance in the body.

questions.text: Comment on the breathing pattern of a patient with prolonged inspiratory spasms that resemble breath holding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Apneustic breathing:

  • Apneustic breathing is marked by prolonged inspiratory spasms, often resembling breath holding. It results from damage to the pons in the brainstem, disrupting normal respiratory control.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cheyne-Stokes breathing: This breathing pattern involves alternating periods of deep, rapid breathing followed by brief periods of apnea. It doesn't match the prolonged inspiratory spasms described.

Option B - Kussmaul breathing: Kussmaul breathing is characterized by deep, rapid, and labored breathing often associated with metabolic acidosis. It doesn't involve prolonged inspiratory spasms resembling breath holding.

Option D - Biot breathing: Biot breathing is characterized by irregular breathing with periods of apnea and hyperpnea. It doesn't specifically involve prolonged inspiratory spasms resembling breath holding.

questions.text: Hypoxic Hypoxia is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option D.

A-V shunt : An A-V (arteriovenous) shunt refers to an abnormal connection between an artery and a vein, bypassing the capillary network.  It is associated with hypoxic hypoxia

Incorrect options:

Option A. CO poisoning: Carbon monoxide (CO) can lead to anemic hypoxia. CO has a strong affinity for hemoglobin, binding to it more readily than oxygen. This reduces the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood, resulting in decreased oxygen delivery to the tissues.

Option B. HCN poisoning: Hydrogen cyanide (HCN) poisoning can cause Histotoxic hypoxia. HCN inhibits cellular respiration by interfering with the electron transport chain, impairing the utilization of oxygen by the cells.

Option C. Ischemia: Ischemia refers to inadequate blood flow to tissues, which can result in stagnant hypoxia. Reduced blood flow means less oxygen is delivered to the affected tissues, leading to hypoxia.

questions.text: What would be the resulting lung volume if the chest wall is excluded and the lung is allowed to undergo elastic recoil?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A.

  • Minimum volume: The minimum volume of the lung refers to the volume of the lung when it is allowed to undergo maximum elastic recoil without any opposing forces from the chest wall. It is the smallest volume the lung can reach during expiration.

Incorrect options 

Option B. Zero: If the lung undergoes elastic recoil without the chest wall, it does not mean that the lung volume would reach zero. The lungs still have residual air and do not collapse completely.

Option C. Functional residual capacity (FRC): FRC is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal expiration, when the forces of lung recoil and chest wall expansion are in equilibrium. It is the volume at which the lung and chest wall exert equal but opposite forces.

Option D. Residual volume: The residual volume is the volume of air that remains in the lungs after a maximal expiration. It represents the air that cannot be expelled from the lungs and serves to keep the alveoli open.

The O2 saturation with respect to PO₂ is marked as A. What happens to the Oxygen Hb dissociation curve upon transfusion of stored RBC?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) B

 

Explanation:

  • Stored RBCs have reduced 2,3-BPG levels due to metabolic depletion during storage.
  • 2,3-BPG normally promotes oxygen unloading by decreasing hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen.
  • With low 2,3-BPG, hemoglobin binds oxygen more tightly, leading to a leftward shift (Curve B) in the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve.
  • This results in impaired oxygen delivery to tissues, as hemoglobin holds onto oxygen more strongly.

Decreases oxygen unloading

 

C (Option B): Incorrect because stored RBCs initially reduce oxygen unloading (left shift) rather than increasing it.

D (Option C): Incorrect because a linear curve does not reflect the physiological response to stored RBC transfusion.

Correct Answer Option A - Dipalmitoyl Phosphatidylcholine

Explanation:

Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS):

  • Surfactant is produced by Type II pneumocytes.

  • Surfactant production begins by 20-24 weeks and matures by 35-37 weeks.

  • Surfactant is a mixture of phospholipids, proteins, and ions.

  • Dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine, surfactant apoproteins, and calcium ions are the most important components. (Option A)

  • They are primarily responsible for reducing surface tension by partially dissolving in the fluid lining the alveolar surface while the rest spreads over the water's surface in the alveoli.

questions.text: During exercise, once a state of balance is achieved, it was observed that the body's oxygen consumption rate was 1500 ml/min. To determine the MET score, consider a baseline oxygen consumption rate of 250 ml/min.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 6

Explanation:

  • MET (Metabolic Equivalent of Task) is a unit used to estimate energy expenditure during physical activity, defined as the ratio of metabolic rate during activity to resting metabolic rate.

Formula to Calculate MET:

MET = Oxygen consumption during exercise/ Resting oxygen consumption

Given:

  • Oxygen consumption during exercise = 1500 ml/min
  • Resting oxygen consumption = 250 ml/min

Calculation:

MET = 1500 ml/min/ 250 ml/min= 6

Thus, the MET score is 6, indicating that the energy expenditure during exercise is 6 times higher than at rest.

 

Factors affecting MET:

  • Body weight: Heavier individuals generally have a higher absolute energy expenditure during physical activities than lighter individuals.
  • Fitness level: More physically fit tend to have a more efficient cardiovascular system and improved oxygen utilization, resulting in lower energy expenditure for the same activity than individuals with lower fitness levels.
  • Age: Generally, younger individuals have a higher metabolic rate and may expend more energy during physical activities than older individuals.
  • Activity duration and intensity: Longer durations or higher intensity activities result in higher energy expenditure.
  • Body composition: Individuals with a higher percentage of lean muscle mass typically have a higher metabolic rate and may expend more energy during physical activities.
  • Environmental factors: Extreme temperatures or high altitudes can increase the body’s energy demands, leading to higher energy expenditure and potentially higher MET values.

questions.text: Peripheral chemoreceptors are most sensitive to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hypoxia

 

Explanation:

  • Peripheral chemoreceptors (carotid and aortic bodies) primarily respond to low arterial oxygen (PaO₂).
  • They are activated when PaO₂ falls below 60 mmHg, increasing ventilation to restore oxygen levels.
  • While they also respond to hypercapnia and acidosis, the central chemoreceptors in the medulla are more sensitive to CO₂ and pH changes.

Peripheral Chemoreceptors and Their Sensitivity

Stimulus

Effect on Peripheral Chemoreceptors

Hypoxia (↓ PaO₂)

Strongest stimulus, leading to increased ventilation.

Hypercapnia (↑ PaCO₂)

Weak response; central chemoreceptors dominate.

Acidosis (↓ pH)

Peripheral response occurs, but central chemoreceptors are more significant.

Alkalosis (↑ pH)

Minimal effect; detected mainly by central chemoreceptors.

Hypercapnia (Option A): Incorrect because central chemoreceptors primarily regulate CO₂ levels, while peripheral chemoreceptors have a weaker response.

Acidosis (Option C): Incorrect because although peripheral chemoreceptors detect acidosis, central chemoreceptors play a dominant role.

Alkalosis (Option D): Incorrect because alkalosis does not significantly stimulate peripheral chemoreceptors.

questions.text: Physiological dead space?

choices.text: Is lesser than anatomical dead space

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Represents inadequately perfused alveoli

 

Explanation:

  • Physiological dead space includes both anatomical dead space (conducting airways) and alveolar dead space (alveoli that are ventilated but not perfused).
  • It occurs when some alveoli receive air but lack sufficient blood flow, leading to inefficient gas exchange.
  • It is calculated using Bohr’s equation, which considers the difference between arterial and expired CO₂ levels.

Physiological Dead Space

Concept

Description

Anatomical Dead Space

Conducting airways where no gas exchange occurs (e.g., trachea, bronchi).

Alveolar Dead Space

Alveoli that are ventilated but not perfused, contributing to wasted ventilation.

Physiological Dead Space

Sum of anatomical and alveolar dead space; reflects ineffective ventilation.

Can be measured by spirometry (Option A): Incorrect because spirometry measures lung volumes but cannot differentiate dead space ventilation.

Is lesser than anatomical dead space (Option B): Incorrect because physiological dead space is always equal to or greater than anatomical dead space.

Represents inadequately ventilated alveoli (Option C): Incorrect because it is related to perfusion failure, not ventilation failure (which occurs in shunt physiology).

questions.text: A patient presents with respiratory difficulty and a history of chronic smoking. Pulmonary function testing shows a decrease in FEV1%. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)

 

Explanation:

A history of chronic smoking and decreased FEV₁% (forced expiratory volume in 1 second as a percentage of forced vital capacity) are hallmarks of obstructive lung disease, with COPD being the most probable diagnosis.

  • Key Features of COPD:
    • Chronic smoking history is the most significant risk factor.
    • Obstructive pattern on spirometry:
      • ↓ FEV₁ (forced expiratory volume in 1 sec)
      • ↓ FEV₁/FVC ratio (<70%) → hallmark of airflow obstruction
    • Progressive dyspnoea, chronic cough, sputum production
    • Irreversible airflow limitation

Features of Obstructive Diseases:

  1. Total Lung Capacity is normal or increased
  2. Residual Volume is elevated due to trapping of air during expiration
  3. The ratio of RV/TLC is increased
  4. Vital Capacity frequently decreases (not due to decreased lung volumes but increased RV).
  5. FEV is less than 80% of TLC
  6. FEV/FVC decreases
  7. MMFR (Maximum Mid-Expiratory Flow Rate) decreases

 

Emphysema:

Chronic infection

↓

Impaired mucus clearance + Excess mucus secretion + Inflammatory edema

↓

Bronchiolar obstruction

↓

Air trapping and Alveolar damage

↓

Elevated RV and TLC

 

Examples of obstructive lung disease:

  • Asthma
  • COPD (Chronic bronchitis and emphysema)
  • Bronchiectasis
  • Bronchiolitis
  • Cystic fibrosis

 

Pulmonary Fibrosis (Option B) is incorrect because pulmonary fibrosis is a restrictive lung disease, which shows decreased FVC but normal or increased FEV₁/FVC ratio.


 

Interstitial Lung Disease (Option C) is incorrect because interstitial lung diseases (ILDs) cause a restrictive pattern, with normal or increased FEV₁/FVC rather than a decreased ratio.


 

Asthma (Option D) is incorrect because while asthma also causes obstructive airway disease with a low FEV₁%, it is typically reversible with bronchodilators, unlike COPD, which is progressive and largely irreversible.

questions.text: Which ion is primarily involved in the function of O2-sensitive channels in peripheral chemoreceptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Potassium (K+)
Explanation:

  • The ion primarily involved in the function of O₂-sensitive channels in peripheral chemoreceptors is Potassium (K⁺).
  • These channels play a crucial role in oxygen sensing within the carotid bodies, which are the main chemoreceptor sites for detecting changes in blood oxygen levels.
  • When oxygen levels drop, the O₂-sensitive potassium channels close, leading to cell depolarization and the subsequent release of neurotransmitters that signal the brain to increase respiration and blood pressure to maintain oxygen homeostasis​

Sodium (Na⁺) (Option B): is not directly involved in the O2-sensitive channels. They play a different role in other cellular processes but are not the key ions for oxygen sensitivity in peripheral chemoreceptors.

Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) (Option C): is involved in acid-base balance and buffering, not directly in the function of O2-sensitive channels.

Chloride (Cl⁻) (Option D): does not play a direct role in the functioning of O2-sensitive channels in peripheral chemoreceptors.

questions.text: Carbon monoxide causes which type of hypoxia?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Anemic Hypoxia

Explanation:

  • Anemic hypoxia results from insufficient or impaired hemoglobin thus leading to decreased oxygen transport and causing hypoxia.

Anemic Hypoxia

Definition: Normal PO2 of arterial blood but inadequate hemoglobin (Hb) to carry O2.

Causes:

  • Anaemia (decreased Hb concentration)
  • Carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning
  • Altered Hb (e.g., Methemoglobin)

Mechanism:

  • Normal PO2: PO2 in inspired air and arterial blood is normal.
  • Reduced O2 Transport: Inadequate Hb reduces O2 supply to tissues.
  • Mild/Moderate Anemia: Increased 2,3-DPG in red cells compensates for low Hb; severe hypoxia during exercise.
  • CO Poisoning:
    • CO binds to Hb with 210 times greater affinity than O2, forming carboxyhemoglobin (COHb).
    • Slow release of CO from COHb prevents O2 binding.
  • Normal Hb content, but Hb is unavailable for O2 transport.
  • Hb-dissociation curve shifts left, decreasing O2 release to tissues.

Incorrect Options:

Hypoxic hypoxia (Option B): It is caused by low arterial PO2 due to factors like high altitude or respiratory disease, not related to haemoglobin levels

Stagnant hypoxia (Option C): It occurs due to reduced blood flow or cardiac output, causing inadequate tissue perfusion despite normal arterial PO2

Histotoxic hypoxia (Option D): It Involves impaired cellular utilization of oxygen, often due to toxins, despite normal oxygen supply and delivery

questions.text: A preterm baby who was delivered at 28 weeks developed respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following is true about surface tension and compliance in this baby?

choices.text: Both surface tension and compliance decreased
Both surface tension and compliance increased

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Surface tension - increased; Compliance decreased

Explanation:

  • This statement is accurate regarding surface tension and compliance in a preterm baby with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).
  • Elastic tissue recoil and surface tension are the two opposing forces to lung compliance and are not opposing forces to each other.

Two primary factors influence lung compliance:

  • Elastic forces of the lung tissue:
    • These forces are primarily determined by the presence of elastin and collagen fibers within the lung parenchyma (the functional tissue of the lungs).
    • In a deflated lung, these fibers are contracted and kinked. As the lung expands during inspiration, these fibers stretch and unkink, generating an elastic force that opposes further expansion.
  • Surface tension:
    • A thin layer of fluid lines the inside of the alveoli. At the air-fluid interface within the alveoli, surface tension arises from the stronger attraction between water molecules compared to the attraction between water molecules and air molecules.
    • This surface tension creates an inward pull, attempting to minimize the surface area of the fluid lining the alveoli. Consequently, this inward pull contributes to the elastic recoil of the lungs, making them tend to collapse

questions.text: Which of the following conditions will shift the oxygen-Hb dissociation curve to the left?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Alkalosis

Explanation:

Alkalosis shifts the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve to the left, meaning that hemoglobin holds onto oxygen more tightly and has a reduced tendency to release it to tissues. This is because at higher pH (alkalosis), hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen increases.

Hypoxia (option A): Hypoxia causes a rightward shift of the oxygen-Hb dissociation curve, facilitating oxygen release to tissues, as the body responds to low oxygen levels by decreasing hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen.

Hypercarbia (option B): Increased carbon dioxide (hypercarbia) also shifts the oxygen-Hb dissociation curve to the right, enhancing oxygen unloading to tissues to meet the increased metabolic demand.

Increase in 2,3-DPG (option D): An increase in 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG) shifts the curve to the right, promoting oxygen release from hemoglobin to tissues, especially under conditions such as chronic hypoxia or anemia.

questions.text: In the lungs, which type of cells are responsible for the secretion of surfactant?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Type 2 pneumocyte

Explanation:

Type 2 pneumocytes are responsible for the production and secretion of surfactant in the lungs. Surfactant is essential for reducing surface tension in the alveoli, preventing alveolar collapse, and facilitating gas exchange.

Type 1 pneumocyte (option A): Type 1 pneumocytes are involved in the structural formation of the alveolar walls and are responsible for gas exchange, not surfactant production.

Alveolar macrophage (option B): Alveolar macrophages (also called dust cells) are immune cells in the lungs that help clear debris, pathogens, and particles, but they do not secrete surfactant.

Dust cells (option C): Dust cells are another term for alveolar macrophages, which are involved in immune responses and clearing particles from the lungs but do not play a role in surfactant secretion.

questions.text: Which among the following has the highest airway resistance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bronchi

Explanation:

The medium to large-size bronchi, specifically the lobar and segmental bronchi, are the site of maximum resistance to airflow. This is because these bronchi have a relatively larger radius but are fewer in number, resulting in higher individual resistance.

  • According to Poiseuille's law, resistance to airflow (R) is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the radius (r) of the airway.
  • Resistance: R = 8ηL/πr4
  • Therefore, small changes in the radius result in significant changes in resistance. Despite the smaller radius of the bronchioles, their parallel arrangement results in a lower total resistance.

questions.text: Determine the respiratory quotient (RQ) of a patient weighing 50 kg who exhales 200 ml/min of CO2 and consumed 250 ml/min 02.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 0.8

Explanation:

To determine the respiratory quotient (RQ), we use the formula:

  • RQ = VCO2/VO2
  • Given the values:
    • CO2 exhaled (VCO2) = 200 ml/min
    • O2 consumed (VO2) = 250 ml/min
  • Substituting these values into the formula:
    • RQ = 200 ml/min / 250 ml/min RQ = 0.8

questions.text: Adequate oxygen delivery at cellular level is present in which type of hypoxia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Histotoxic:

  • Histotoxic hypoxia occurs when there is a disruption in the utilization of oxygen at the level of the tissue by the cells, despite adequate oxygen delivery.
  • It can be caused by cyanide poisoning and beriberi that interfere with the cellular metabolic processes, preventing the cells from effectively utilizing the oxygen delivered to them.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anemic: Anemic hypoxia results from a decrease in the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood due to reduced hemoglobin levels or abnormal hemoglobin function.

Option B - Stagnant: Stagnant hypoxia arises from the impaired circulation of blood, leading to inadequate oxygen delivery to tissues, as seen in hemorrhage and heart failure.

Option C - Hypoxic: Hypoxic hypoxia is a condition where the partial pressure of oxygen in the arterial blood is too low.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is used for calculation of anatomical dead space ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Single breath nitrogen test: 

  • The single breath nitrogen test is a method used to estimate anatomical dead space. It involves inhaling pure oxygen and then exhaling slowly and steadily.
  • The alveolar oxygen is mixed with the nitrogen whereas the air in the anatomical dead space is free of nitrogen containing only oxygen thus measuring the anatomical dead space

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Multiple breath nitrogen test: It is used for measuring the residual volume.

Option B - Bohr’s method: it is used for measuring the physiological dead space.

Option C - Spirometry: Spirometry is a commonly used test to assess lung function and measure various parameters such as forced vital capacity (FVC), forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1), and peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR).

questions.text: Adequate O2 oxygen delivery at cellular level occurs in which type of hypoxia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Histotoxic:

  • Histotoxic hypoxia occurs when there is a disruption in the utilization of oxygen at the level of the tissue, despite adequate oxygen delivery.
  • It can be caused by cyanide poisoning and beriberi that interfere with the cellular metabolic processes, preventing the cells from effectively utilizing the oxygen delivered to them. In histotoxic hypoxia, the oxygen delivery to tissues is adequate, but the cells are unable to utilize it properly.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hypoxic hypoxia: Hypoxic hypoxia occurs when there is a decrease in the oxygen tension (partial pressure of oxygen) in the arterial blood.

Option B - Anemic hypoxia: Anemic hypoxia results from a decrease in the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood due to reduced hemoglobin levels or abnormal hemoglobin function.

Option C - Stagnant hypoxia: Stagnant hypoxia arises from the impaired circulation of blood, leading to inadequate oxygen delivery to tissues.

questions.text: Which of the following breathing patterns have prolonged inspiratory spasms that resemble breath-holding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Apneustic breathing: 

  • Apneustic breathing is characterized by prolonged inspiratory spasms or gasping breaths that resemble breath-holding with a brief expiration.
  • The apneustic center results in prolonged inspiration by activating inspiratory neurons leading to deeper inspiration.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Biot breathing: Biot breathing is characterized by normal 3 to 4 cycles of breathing followed by abrupt pauses or periods of apnea.

Option C - Cheyne-Stokes breathing: Cheyne-Stokes breathing is characterized by a cyclical pattern of apnea and shallow breathing due to an underlying pathology like congestive heart failure.

Option D - Kussmaul breathing: Kussmaul breathing is a deep and labored breathing pattern often seen in individuals with diabeticketoacidosis.

questions.text: Functional residual capacity is:

choices.text: Volume that remains after forced expiration

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Expiratory reserve volume + residual volume: 

  • Functional residual capacity (FRC) is the volume of air that remains in the lungs after a normal tidal expiration.
  • It is calculated by adding the expiratory reserve volume (the amount of air that can still be exhaled after a normal tidal expiration) to the residual volume and is equal to the 2.3L.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Volume expired after normal inspiration: The volume expired after a normal inspiration is referred to as the tidal volume and is around 500 ml..

Option B - Volume that remains after forced expiration: The volume that remains after a forced expiration is the residual volume and is around 1.2 L.

Option D - Tidal volume + inspiratory reserve volume: The sum of the tidal volume and the inspiratory reserve volume represents inspiratory capacity and is around 3.5L.

questions.text: During forceful expiration, which type of neurons primarily exhibit increased firing?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Caudal Ventral group of neurons:

  • Caudal ventral respiratory group neurons mainly contain the expiratory group of neurons, which is dominantly discharged during forceful expiration.
  • During forceful expiration, one takes the help of the accessory muscles of respiration, for example, the abdominal muscles and internal intercostal muscles.
  • These are all contracted during forceful expiration. This control is exerted by the caudal ventral respiratory group neurons.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dorsal group of neurons: The dorsal group of neurons, also known as the dorsal respiratory group (DRG), is responsible for integrating sensory signals from the peripherals, such as the lungs or the muscles.

Option C - Pneumotaxic center: The pneumotaxic center, also known as the pontine respiratory group, is a part of the brainstem that regulates the rate of breathing.

Option D - Apneustic center: Apneustic center is also a pontine respiratory group that regulates the depth of breathing.

questions.text: What is the affinity of carbon monoxide to hemoglobin in comparison to oxygen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 250: 

  • The affinity of carbon monoxide for hemoglobin is approximately 250 times greater than the affinity of oxygen for hemoglobin. This means that when both gases are present, carbon monoxide will bind to hemoglobin preferentially, reducing the amount of oxygen that can bind and be transported to the body's tissues. This can lead to hypoxia (low oxygen levels) and can be life-threatening.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What would be the least likely condition to happen if a group of colleagues took an excursion to a high altitude-mountain region?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Increase PaO2: 

  • PaO2 is the least likely condition to happen during an excursion to a high-altitude mountain region. At higher altitudes, the partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) decreases due to the lower atmospheric pressure. This can lead to a hypoxia, where there's a reduced availability of oxygen for the body's cells and tissues.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Increase in RBC & Hb: When exposed to lower oxygen levels, the body can adapt by producing more red blood cells and hemoglobin to enhance oxygen-carrying capacity, improving the overall oxygen delivery to tissues.

Option C - Increased mitochondria: To extract the increased amount of oxygen by the tissue, the number of mitochondria and cytochrome oxidase enzymes are increased.

Option D - Hyperventilation: It's the body's attempt to compensate for lower oxygen levels by increasing the respiratory rate to take in more oxygen. This can help temporarily alleviate the effects of hypoxia.

questions.text: V/Q = infinity means ____________

choices.text: Partial pressure of O2 becomes zero
CO2 alone equilibrates with the venous blood
Partial pressure of both CO2 and O2 remain normal

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - No exchange of O2 & CO2:

  • When the ventilation-perfusion ratio (V/Q) is infinite, it means that there is adequate ventilation and no perfusion due to an emboli leading to no exchange of oxygen (O2) and carbon dioxide (CO2) occurring in the lungs.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: Pacemaker generating the rhythm for breathing is ______________

choices.text: Dorsal group of neurons in the medulla

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Pre-Botziger complex:

  • The Pre-Botzinger complex, located in the medulla oblongata, is considered the primary pacemaker for spontaneous breathing. It consists of I (inspiratory) and E (Expiratory) neurons that spontaneously generate rhythmic signals, initiating the pattern of breathing.  

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pneumotaxic centre: The pneumotaxic center, located in the pons of the brainstem, helps regulate the duration and depth of each breath. It controls the switching off of the inspiratory phase, allowing for smoother transitions between inhalation and exhalation.

Option B - Botzinger complex: It contains the expiratory group of neurons, and their main role is to control the expiration.

Option D - Apneustic center: The apneustic center, located in the lower pons of the brainstem, is involved in regulating the intensity and duration of inhalation through inhalatory neuron.

questions.text: Single breath nitrogen method is used for measuring _____________
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Anatomical dead space volume:

  • The single breath nitrogen test, aka fowler’s method is used to estimate anatomical dead space. It involves inhaling pure oxygen and then exhaling slowly and steadily.
  • The alveolar oxygen is mixed with the nitrogen whereas the air in the anatomical dead space is free of nitrogen containing only oxygen thus measuring the anatomical dead space.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Physiological dead space volume: Bohr’s method is used to measure physiological dead space volume.

Option B - Residual Volume: It is calculated by multiple breath nitrogen washout method.

Option C - Tidal volume: It can be calculated by using a spirometer.
